title: What took France so long to abolish the guillotine? - Quora

response.answer_text: La Guillotine wasn't abolished. The death penalty was. In 1981. The last execution took place in 1977, of a man who had tortured a young woman to death. To answer the question now, the death penalty was abolished in France for several reasons. First of all, it used to be public. The reasoning behind that was that people should see justice in action. That was changed because the public was a little bit too enthusiastic at watching real-life gore, up until the 1930s. Then it became for a while “semi-public”, in that the authorities would block the streets in front of the prison. My grandfather, who grew up in front of a prison, had to go to school the long way round when there was an execution. Little by little, the French public became wary of this, unsurprisingly after WW2 when the German occupiers executed a lot of people themselves. Capital punishment moved from for murder, to murder with barbarism. That means a heinous murder, with torture, or against a child. It was finally the “affair of the red pullover” that was the turning point. A man was condemned to be decapitated, but enough doubt existed that he might not be the guilty one. It occurred just before an election, and François Mitterrand won. One of his promises was to end the death penalty. Despite the fact that a slight majority of the population was still in favour of it, it was abolished. It was a political promise that was kept. So the guillotine was abolished because the death penalty was, and that was abolished because enough people voted for a party that had abolishment in its manifesto. For those who wish to see the last used guillotine, it is in the Museum of Mediterrean and European Civilization (MuCEM) in Marseille.

France has never abolished the guillotine itself. It was adopted as a way of making capital punishment as swift, reliable, and painless as possible, and also to end the class distinction in executions. (Nobles were always executed with a sword; commoners could be hanged, burned, boiled, or dismembered depending on the crime.) The last execution in France was in 1977, and the guillotine was still used. The death penalty was abolished in France in 1981, and those still on death row had their sentences commuted.

Because it took so long for France to abolish the death penalty in the first place. The legal methods of execution in France were guillotine and firing squad. They were authorized in 1792. When the death penalty was abolished in 1981 under François Mitterrand, also both guillotine and firing squad were abolished. See Capital punishment in France - Wikipedia.

The interesting point for me is that President George Pompidou (an opponent of capital punishment) was concerned that the penalty was on the books at all. When a particularly grieivous case arose, he argued that if the death penalty was on the books, then it should be used in this case. It was used and the legislature soon abolished the practise.

The death penalty eas nearly abolished in France in 1906. A bill was presented to the French Parliament that had, initially, widespread support , both in Parliament , and in the country. However, just as it was being debated, there was a particularly gruesome rape and murder going through the courts. The perpetrator was found guilty, and was sentenced to death . If the bill had passed, he would have been spared. A particularly fierce campaign to retain the death penalty was started in newspapers by supporters of the death penalty because of this; it swayed public opinion and the votes of the Parliament, which then voted against the abolition by a majority of 100 votes.

In the Middle Ages, execution by beheading with a sword was reserved for aristocrats. It was thought more dignified than hanging or burning. It was certainly less painful The guillotine was a mechanism that brought the benefits of quick clean execution to all and sundry: it was an abolition of an aristocratic privilege. The guillotine was the method of execution on France until the death penalty was abolished on recent years, I think the 1970s.

Thank you for asking me about this, Mark. The guillotine remained the prescribed form of judicial execution in France until she abolished the death penalty in 1981. The rationale behind the instrument was that it gave the condemned person a quick, merciful death. Sadly, the conclusion of modern scientific thinking is that this was a mistaken belief. Fifty-three countries around the world retain the death penalty on their statute books.
